title: How to Feel Better when Depressed

steps.title: If you’re having a bad day, that’s okay.
steps.content: If you’re having a bad day, that’s okay. It’s fine to accept your feelings for what they are without trying to change them. If you want to let them out, talk to a friend or write them down in a journal. If you start to feel better, let yourself feel the good feelings, too. [1] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source It’s okay to wallow in your feelings a little bit. Trying to suppress them or not to feel them is actually unhealthy, and it can worsen your mental health in the long run. [2] X Research source Remember that just because you’re feeling bad today doesn’t necessarily mean you’ll feel bad tomorrow.

steps.title: Your friends and family members can help you through it.
steps.content: Your friends and family members can help you through it. You can let them know what you’ve been going through, or you can simply chat with them to distract you from your thoughts. Try to text, call, or hang out with someone at least once a day to get some social activity in. [3] X Expert Source Michelle Shahbazyan, MS, MA Life Coach, Author, and Speaker Expert Interview. 18 March 2020. [4] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source When you’re feeling depressed, it’s natural to want to isolate yourself from others. However, this can actually make you feel worse, [5] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source so it’s important to fight those feelings.

steps.title: If you don’t enjoy anything, do something you used to enjoy.
steps.content: If you don’t enjoy anything, do something you used to enjoy. This could be absolutely anything: painting, running, hiking, watching a movie, hanging out with friends, riding your bike, or cooking a meal. [6] X Expert Source Michelle Shahbazyan, MS, MA Life Coach, Author, and Speaker Expert Interview. 18 March 2020. If it makes you feel good (or you think it might make you feel good), then do it! [7] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source Try to do something that you enjoy at least once a day.

steps.title: Let your feelings out by doing some art.
steps.content: Let your feelings out by doing some art. You could draw, paint, work with clay, take some pictures, or make a collage. It doesn’t have to be a masterpiece—focus on having fun and enjoying the process. [8] X Research source If you don’t have any art supplies, that’s okay! Grab a pencil and a sheet of paper and try drawing something.

steps.title: Write about how you’re feeling or what you did that day.
steps.content: Write about how you’re feeling or what you did that day. Don’t worry if it makes sense or not—just write! Try to write in your journal once a day for a fun way to express yourself and let out your emotions. [9] X Trustworthy Source Mind U.K.-based mental health charity focused on providing advice and resources to anyone facing mental health problems. Go to source Keep your journal in a private place that no one else can access. That way, you can write about whatever you want.

steps.title: Nature can really make you feel better.
steps.content: Nature can really make you feel better. If it’s a nice day out, go for a walk around your neighborhood or check out a hiking trail nearby. If it’s a gloomy day, try going for a drive or taking the bus just to look at the sky. [10] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source If you have a pet, take them with you on a walk so you can both get some exercise. If you’re at work or school, try to spend your lunch break outdoors. Reader Poll: We asked 154 wikiHow readers, and 88% said that spending time in nature boosts their mood . [Take Poll] Whether it’s a walk in the woods, a picnic in the park, or a night of stargazing, it’s scientifically proven that connecting with nature makes you less stressed, more confident, and happier. And our readers agree!

steps.title: What’s one good thing that’s happened this week?
steps.content: What’s one good thing that’s happened this week? When we’re depressed, it’s tough to remember that good things actually do happen. Try to think about something uplifting (or even something neutral) that happened to you recently. [11] X Research source This doesn’t have to be some huge epiphany. It could be as small as getting a fun coffee yesterday or seeing a cute dog on your way home.

steps.title: Give your full attention to where you are now.
steps.content: Give your full attention to where you are now. Try not to think of the past or the future; instead, think about what you’re doing and who you’re with. This can take some practice, but with time, mindfulness can help you focus your thoughts and center your mind. [12] X Expert Source Michelle Shahbazyan, MS, MA Life Coach, Author, and Speaker Expert Interview. 18 March 2020. [13] X Trustworthy Source Mind U.K.-based mental health charity focused on providing advice and resources to anyone facing mental health problems. Go to source You might also find it helpful to meditate.

steps.title: Exercise releases endorphins that make you feel good.
steps.content: Exercise releases endorphins that make you feel good. Although it might seem tough, try to get up and get moving at least once a day. You could dance, swim, ride a bike, jog, lift weight, or jump rope. Whatever it is, do it for 15 to 30 minutes to get your heart pumping and your blood flowing. [14] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source If you’re feeling super unmotivated, call a friend to come over and exercise with you. It’s harder to back out of getting active when there’s someone else counting on you.

steps.title: It will give you the right nutrition that you need.
steps.content: It will give you the right nutrition that you need. Try to fill your diet with lean protein, fruit, vegetables, and whole grains. Eat sweets in moderation, and stick to water when you’re thirsty. [15] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source It can be tough to make yourself meals when you’re feeling depressed. Go for easy-to-prepare foods like hard boiled eggs, sandwiches, and pasta so you can still eat something when you have low energy.

steps.title: Many people with depression experience sleep issues.
steps.content: Many people with depression experience sleep issues. If you’re sleeping too little, you might feel groggy or lethargic throughout the day. If you’re sleeping too much, you might feel disoriented or have brain fog. Aim for around 8 hours of sleep per night to give your body the rest it needs. [16] X Research source If your schedule allows for it, try to sleep at night and stay awake during the day. Taking multiple naps when the sun is out can throw off your biological clock, making it harder to sleep.

steps.title: Depression isn’t easy to tackle on your own.
steps.content: Depression isn’t easy to tackle on your own. If you’re struggling with your mental health, reach out to a therapist or counselor to help you cope. If you have health insurance, get a referral from your doctor for a licensed professional. If you don’t, consider a cheaper option like online counseling. [17] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Contrary to popular belief, you don’t always have to take medication in order to treat depression. You and your therapist can figure out what’s right for you, but you may be able to make lifestyle changes and use talk therapy to improve your mental health. [18] X Research source
